player_decision.reason: Button with suited connector in 3-handed; open min-raise to steal blinds with position and keep pot manageable.

Ah Qh in a three-handed preflop with Alice’s 20 bet and Bob waiting behind is strong but not a guaranteed winner. Calling 15 to match the 20 leaves us with a solid equity edge and the possibility of a favorable flop (top pair/top kicker, backdoor hearts) without committing too many chips. It also keeps us in position to apply pressure on later streets if the flop comes favorable.
Holding 2-7 offsuit — the worst starting hand. Facing an open and a call (multiway), calling or raising is negative EV. Preserve stack and fold.

On the flop with AhQh vs a 20 bet on Jh 8s 3s, we have 6 clean outs to top pair (A or Q) plus a backdoor heart flush draw (~4%). Combined equity ~18–24%. Pot odds (~20 to call into ~70–75) are roughly break-even to slightly positive, so calling is the correct, conservative play to realize our redraws.
Check back to pot-control and realize equity with a weak bottom pair on a wet board; avoid getting check-jammed by draws or Jx with shallow SPR.

AhQh on Jh 8s 3s turn 9c gives me a backdoor heart flush draw and top Ace high outs exist; with no clear value bet from the opponent, I’ll check/call to control the pot and see the river for potential improvements.

Opponent has checked twice into a 50 pot; our pair of 3s is likely ahead but vulnerable. Bet ~60% pot to deny equity from overcards/spades and take it down often, while keeping room to fold if check-raised.

AhQh on a J-9-8-3 rainbow board with one heart. Facing a 30 bet on the turn from AliceAI with no real outs (no flush or straight draws likely to hit). Folding preserves 70 chips for later hands in a 3-handed game.
